So there are I believe for types of bows
Long bow- the limbs of the bow are straight and bow usually long string is pulled by fingers
Recurve bow- the limbs recurve backwards where the string attaches (most common today) shorter then long bow string is pulled by fingers
Horse bow-bow is usually very short and looks like a mini recurve string pulled by fingers
Compound bow- most used today for hunting but very short and uses a lot of technology compounds shoot faster than all other bows fps wise and are generally easier to be very accurate because of the sighting system and how the string is released. The string is released using a release which is mechanical and releases the string perfect every time. The cams of a compound bow at the ends of the limbs use technology that allows the archer to have what's called let off meaning if a bow is 60 lbs in pull weight and the bow as a let off of 80 percent then the archer will only feel 20 percent of the original pull weight when the string is fully pulled ( depending on what's called draw length which differs between shooters).
What this archer is doing is beyond difficult a 70lb pull weight with no let off no sights being that accurate is ridiculous and an amazing skill. If you wonder that 70lbs doesn't sound like much imagine 70lbs of weight on a string and u have to pull the string back 29 inches using only three fingers and u would have an idea how hard that would be.

This is used to counter the "archers paradox"
Khatra or Khatrah in archery is a technique and style of release.
Khatra describes the natural follow-through of the bow hand upon release of the arrow.
The Khatra technique is typically performed in one of two ways.
1 Pressing the bow downwards and forward upon release.
2 Pressing and/or turning the bow outwards, away from the center of the body upon release.

The video is completely wrong on sights. Sights on a bow actually hinder your ability to make quick accurate shots. I use a compound bow and intentionally don't use sights just for this reason, even timing myself on how fast I can shoot arrows, another thing sights will hold you back on. I've seen guys who won awards try and make up close shots with a sighted bow and they can't do it quick or accurately, especially if the top pin is sighted for anything beyond what they are shooting at. Sights are more like the sniper shooting for bows. You aren't' going to quick fire, or try to shoot anything up close with a sniper rifle. you'll knock that target out 100 yards out with pretty amazing accuracy though. That's a good way to put it really. Sightless bow shooting is more like the pistol equivalent, while sighted shooting is like the sniper.

I'm sorry Destin but the circle packing number has nothing to do with the difficulty of the shot.
Rather use the target area as a baseline as this is directly related to the chance of hitting it on purpose.

The packing number is just that: the number of disjoint balls that fit in a space whereas the number of possible points you can hit is infinite, thus warranting a continuous distribution (i.e. integrating over the target area).

Circle packing factor doesn't really mean anything to this problem, as the arrow is not limited to the packing factor hit points, as well as the grazing hit you do mention above.  For the relative difficulty of hitting the smaller target to the larger, it is just the diameter of the target + (slightly less than, the overlap of the arrow to the target to generate a noticeable hit, if you will) the diameter of the arrow quantity squared of the first (smaller) target over the same equation for the larger target. I have a question/observation maybe you could shed some light on. The object being thrown is gradually slowed due to gravity until it reaches it's peak height and a velocity of 0. At this point it turns around and begins it's acceleration in the other direction. Because of this, the objects spends the most time near the peak of its trajectory. I noticed during Bryon's shots, that he seemed to be hitting the objects thrown during their initial descent. This got me to thinking of what might be easier - shooting the arrow as it rises toward the peak (mentally calculating where the peak will be), or shooting the arrow as the object reaches its peak (mentally calculating where it will be soon after the peak)? Or are they the same? It would be interesting to work backward from the observed velocity of the arrow and the time of contact with the object to find just when Bryon fired his arrow as a function of the the objects position in it's trajectory.

Great video, I've been a fan of Byron for years! One thing should be noted however. It wouldn't be easier to make those shots with a modern bow. It would in fact be more difficult. If we're talking about a hitting a stationary target then yes, absolutely it would be easier with a modern bow & sights, but when shooting at aerial targets the traditional long bow is the superior system. Think about it as a rifle verses a shotgun. I'm not talking about one bullet verses a bunch of pellets but rather the sighting systems & techniques of shooting the two different weapons. On a rifle you have a good set of sights much like a modern compound bow, but using those sights to hit a flying target, even if they're on something like a turkey shotgun shooting the same ammo as any other shotgun, is extremely difficult. On a normal shotgun like a bird gun there are no sights, just a small bead on the front of the gun, and you shoot it by looking at the target. It's the same with a long bow & a compound bow. Having sights would only make hitting those flying target more difficult.

All of that being said, I want to be absolutely clear about one thing. I am not in any way saying what Byron was doing is easy! I shoot both modern compound bows and traditional recurve bows, and I couldn't even begin to hit a flying target like that!

Lars may appear more impressive, but in terms of accuracy and consistency he is nothing close to comparable with Byron. He uses a 35lb and half draws it making the real weight in the 15-20lb range vs Byron's 70lb bow. Byron is without question the superior archer in terms of accuracy, consistency and ultimately if combat were any measure the Byron would win.
